Analise o estado de risco de cada aplicativo

Verifique as atualizações dos aplicativos baixados
Acompanhe o tempo de tela do seu dispositivo

"Overview

Android made its official public debut in 2008 with Android 1.0, marking the beginning of the Android operating system. This initial release lacked a cute codename." "

Android 1.1 (API 2):

Released on February 9, 2009, the Android 1.1 update, internally known as "Petit Four," was initially available for the HTC Dream. This update addressed bugs, made changes to the Android API, and introduced new features, laying the foundation for the evolution of the Android platform.

Detail

This Android version introduced several notable features. The Android Market facilitated application downloads and updates, while the web browser allowed the viewing of full HTML and XHTML web pages through multiple windows. Camera support was present, but customization options were limited. Folders were introduced for organizing app icons on the Home screen." "Email services included access to web servers and synchronization with Gmail, Google Contacts, and Google Calendar. Google Maps with Street View provided map and satellite imagery, while Google Sync managed over-the-air synchronization. The device supported Wi-Fi and Bluetooth, and the media player allowed management and playback of media files, excluding video and stereo Bluetooth support." "Notifications appeared in the Status bar with customizable alerts. Messaging options encompassed instant messaging, text messaging, and MMS. The voice dialer enabled hands-free calling, and users could set wallpapers behind Home screen icons. Other applications included YouTube, Alarm Clock, Calculator, Dialer, Home screen, Pictures, and Settings. Connectivity details were available when searching for businesses on Maps. Additionally, enhancements included a longer in-call screen timeout, dial-pad show/hide functionality, attachment saving in messages, and support for marquee in system layouts."

"Overview

The inception of Android version names dates back to the early 2009 release of Android 1.5 Cupcake. This milestone brought about several enhancements to the Android interface, notably introducing the inaugural on-screen keyboard. This innovation became essential as phones transitioned away from the previously prevalent physical keyboard model.

Detail

Support for third-party virtual keyboards with text prediction and a user dictionary for custom words.
Support for Widgets – miniature application views that can be embedded in other applications (such as the Home screen) and receive periodic updates.
Video recording and playback in MPEG-4 and 3GP formats.
Auto-pairing and stereo support for Bluetooth (A2DP and AVRCP profiles).
Copy and paste features in the web browser.
User pictures shown for Favorites in Contacts.
Specific date/time stamp shown for events in the call log, and one-touch access to a contact card from a call log event.
Animated screen transitions.
Auto-rotation option.
New stock boot animation.
Ability to upload videos to YouTube.
Ability to upload photos to Picasa.
Ability to check phone usage history."

Overview

On September 15, 2009, Android 1.6, named Donut and built on Linux kernel 2.6.29, was released, introducing numerous features. Notable enhancements included a refined interface, the Quick Search Box for swift device and web searches, and Voice Search functionality. The Android Market received updates for better app organization, and camera and camcorder functionalities were improved.

Detail

Voice and text entry search was enhanced in Android 1.6.
Donut now including bookmark history, contacts, and web results.
Developers gained the ability to include their content in search results, expanding the reach and integration of applications.
The release featured a multi-lingual speech synthesis engine, enabling any Android application to "speak" a string of text.Android Market improvements allowed for easier searching and the ability to view app screenshots, enhancing the user experience.
The Gallery, Camera, and camcorder functions were more fully integrated, offering faster camera access and the capability for users to select multiple photos for deletion
.Technical support received updates for CDMA/EVDO, 802.1x, VPNs, and a text-to-speech engine, enhancing connectivity and accessibility features
.Donut introduced support for WVGA screen resolutions.
